text: Heard of two, never used any of those. Given the replies above, maybe something to take into account :)

text:
Not really related to SEO but quite related to Content. We’re currently exploring onboarding with a tool called Narrativa (<https://www.narrativa.com/>). In a nutshell it’s a tool that can create thousands of pieces of content provided we give it sample materials and data through NLG/AI/whatever other buzzword you can think of. The idea for us is to use it to create content tailored for multiple websites based on their tone/brand voice and language.

However, we’re not quite sold and want to understand where the scene is at at the moment. I could not find any direct competitor easily so I thought maybe this community has encountered/used a company providing a similar software and could guide me so that I can present options to the rest of our Content Marketing team :slightly_smiling_face:

Have a nice one :muscle::skin-tone-3:

text: FYI, I tried both for a bit. Grammarly won out because it has a desktop app and worked in Notion (whereas Writer did not). I could see the style guide being cool if we had a big team, but as an individual user, Grammarly was the better choice.

elements.text: FYI, I tried both for a bit. Grammarly won out because it has a desktop app and worked in Notion (whereas Writer did not). I could see the style guide being cool if we had a big team, but as an individual user, Grammarly was the better choice.

text:
<@U013W748P7T>

AI is nowhere near the ability to create content with the solid voice and ability of a seasoned writer.

I think it's gotten to the point where it can intelligibly string words together, and we may be at the point where it's cheaper than hiring junior writers to cobble together 101 articles and fluff pieces.

But real writing talent does stuff like:

• *Clever structuring:* arranging the energy of a story so that you keep the Reader engaged and interested, plucking at emotions at the right time, getting heavy when they're ready and taking your foot off the gas when it's time for a parsing rest.
• *Wit and charm:* based on the target audience, will they appreciate a cheeky dig at the gaming industry? A straight up Golden Girls meme? A few serious tweets? Or just solid prose that understands how to pace and break grammar rules for effect?
• *Voice conviction:* how do you sound authorative without being pushy? Are you drawing on a source, experience, research, superlatives, history... a blend? 
I could go on. The nuance of excellent written communication is something AI cannot achieve today. It's using very smart and complex algos to make sentences _intelligible_, not _well-written_.

So you have to ask yourself: should we be investing in producing content that ain't well-written? Just "passable-ish?" It might work, if your clients just need wordcount to fill stuff up and you're willing to pass the AI draft to some good editors that can smooth it out. Or maybe the target audiences are not English as a first language, and the AI baseline stuff is 'good enough' for whatever strategy is at hand.

Anywho, if AI can process the subtleties of human emotion via written word well enough to be more cost effective than a good human writer, I believe we'll have bigger issues at hand... namely the whole _"oh shit we've achieved General AI, is Super AI already here? uh oh civilization as we know is about to get WEIRD"_ (<https://medium.com/mapping-out-2050/distinguishing-between-narrow-ai-general-ai-and-super-ai-a4bc44172e22>)

^ (Per that article's definition, ALL content AI stuff is firmly 'Narrow AI')

attachments.fallback: Medium: Distinguishing between Narrow AI, General AI and Super AI
attachments.title: Distinguishing between Narrow AI, General AI and Super AI
